XXI, Otho, in the mean time, felt every motive that could inflame ambition. In quiet times he had nothing before him but despair; trouble and confusion were his only source of hope. His luxury was too great for the revenue of a prince (a), and his fortune was sunk to the lowest ebb, below the condition of a private man. He hated Galba, and he saw Piso with an eye of envy. To these incentives he added real or imaginary fears for his own personal safety, and in those fears he found new motives for rebellion." He had. felt the*' weight of Nero's displeasure; and must'* he now wait for a second Lusitania?" Was he to expect, under colour of" friendship, another honourable banish-" ment?
